title.narrative: Knowledge collection on sports-based NGO work

description.narrative: 1. Overview of sports-based NGOs’ activities in the MENA-region and the various approaches they use in their work. 2. Specific issues addressed in four lessons learned reports based on study tours and joint seminars amongst sports-based NGOs, led by CCPA in consultation with GAME and street football world: 1.1 Report on different approaches to the use of sport as a platform for volunteerism and strengthening of civil society. 1.2 Report focusing on gender issues and dynamics when working with sports-based approaches to humanitarian work. 1.3 Report focusing on the different approaches, dynamics and outcomes in rural and urban settings. 1.4 Report on the possibilities for sports-based humanitarian work in crime prevention and anti-radicalisation.

title.narrative: Knowledge collection on sports-based NGO work

description.narrative: 1. Overview of sports-based NGOs’ activities in the MENA-region and the various approaches they use in their work. 2. Specific issues addressed in four lessons learned reports based on study tours and joint seminars amongst sports-based NGOs, led by CCPA in consultation with GAME and street football world: 1.1 Report on different approaches to the use of sport as a platform for volunteerism and strengthening of civil society. 1.2 Report focusing on gender issues and dynamics when working with sports-based approaches to humanitarian work. 1.3 Report focusing on the different approaches, dynamics and outcomes in rural and urban settings. 1.4 Report on the possibilities for sports-based humanitarian work in crime prevention and anti-radicalisation.

title.narrative: Community-based sports activities as a platform for civic engagement

description.narrative: 1.1 Capacity-building of youth to become leaders in community-based activities. 1.2 Engagement of youth as volunteers in community-based, meaningful activities. 1.3. Children, parents and other relevant community members are involved in meaningful activities creating integration and understanding across gender, social, ethnic and religious divides. 1.4. Engagement of local authorities, police and other relevant stakeholders in community-based, meaningful activities creating cooperation across sectors (expanded and consolidated in output 2 and 3).

title.narrative: Community-based sports activities as a platform for civic engagement

description.narrative: 1.1 Capacity-building of youth to become leaders in community-based activities. 1.2 Engagement of youth as volunteers in community-based, meaningful activities. 1.3. Children, parents and other relevant community members are involved in meaningful activities creating integration and understanding across gender, social, ethnic and religious divides. 1.4. Engagement of local authorities, police and other relevant stakeholders in community-based, meaningful activities creating cooperation across sectors (expanded and consolidated in output 2 and 3).

comment.narrative: 1. While Tunisia, Jordan and Morocco are in relative stability, the populations are in a post-revolution state following the Arab spring of 2011 and face extreme challenges of poverty and youth unemployment, threats from radical elements, social tensions and internal conflicts, gender inequality and limited human rights. 2. There is poor tradition for engagement in civil society activities and volunteerism and youth lack platforms for communicating and operationalizing their visions for their communities and societies 3. While sports activities in formal clubs exist, there is a lack of access to inclusive sports activities for children of all socio-economic backgrounds, especially the most vulnerable, i.e. refugees, disableded and orphaned children. 4. There are few – if any - concerted and united efforts across sectors with the capacity to design and implement meaningful activities promoting peaceful co-existence, gender equality and respect for human rights.

description.narrative: 2.1. Knowledge and capacity-building of 120 youth leaders in sports event management 2.2. The 120 youth leaders have gained planning and implementation skills in so-called big events (vs. smaller events such as OFFS) with a point of departure in the national HUB24, and used those events for public diplomacy purposes 2.3. Cross-sectorial SSP partnerships are formed and active across regional, national and local levels coordinated by a national SSP-coordinator based at the Ministry of Youth and Sports in each country 2.4. Engagement of the national network of young volunteers in the organisation of HUB24s in partnership with SSP-practitioners’ network 2.5. Minimum 9,600 youths have participated in the HUB24.

2.1. Knowledge and capacity-building of 120 youth leaders in sports event management 2.2. The 120 youth leaders have gained planning and implementation skills in so-called big events (vs. smaller events such as OFFS) with a point of departure in the national HUB24, and used those events for public diplomacy purposes 2.3. Cross-sectorial SSP partnerships are formed and active across regional, national and local levels coordinated by a national SSP-coordinator based at the Ministry of Youth and Sports in each country 2.4. Engagement of the national network of young volunteers in the organisation of HUB24s in partnership with SSP-practitioners’ network 2.5. Minimum 9,600 youths have participated in the HUB24.

comment.narrative: 2.1. Based on experience, sports leadership in itself is difficult to turn into a livelihood, whereas there is a trend of popular sports events increasingly becoming an industry across the world. It therefore makes sense to provide young volunteers with hands-on experience of sports event management skills, so that they can take the lead in organizing such events locally and nationally, rather than global actors already prominent within the area. There are currently few - if any - initiatives with this focus in the MENA-region 2.2. There are few – if any - concerted and formalised efforts among authorities, police and other relevant actors with the capacity to design and implement joint ventures for youth and children, which can provide meaningful activities ensuring peaceful co-existence, gender equality and respect for human rights, and ultimately prevent young people from entering into criminal or radicalisation processes.

title.narrative: Fundraising, sustainable structures and crime prevention/anti-radicalisation
Fundraising, sustainable structures and crime prevention/anti-radicalisation

comment.narrative: 3.1. In our experience, many project activities end after ended programme cycle, due to lack of funds 3.2. The building of networks of actors doing civil society work has shown to be of vital importance in our previous projects, since the countries in question lack a strong tradition for volunteerism and civil society work.

description.narrative: The youth have built capacity to carry out volunteer work enhancing interaction and understanding between children and youth of different backgrounds and genders, and gained a platform to voice their visions for society. The youth work within a sustainable structure of youth sports networks and cross sectorial-networks with capacity to work and fundraise for a peaceful co-existence, including crime prevention and anti-radicalisation.

The youth have built capacity to carry out volunteer work enhancing interaction and understanding between children and youth of different backgrounds and genders, and gained a platform to voice their visions for society. The youth work within a sustainable structure of youth sports networks and cross sectorial-networks with capacity to work and fundraise for a peaceful co-existence, including crime prevention and anti-radicalisation.

comment.narrative:
1. The youth in Jordan, Tunisia and Morocco were at the frontlines of the popular uprisings in Arab countries in 2011. Since then, youth have however been excluded and disenfranchised from the decision-making and state-building processes. In contexts where a strong a-political civil society is still only being build, the youth lack platforms to express and operationalize their visions for society. 2. There is little tradition, and few platforms for civil society work and volunteer work. It is however our experience that there is a huge willingness to carry out volunteer work and do good for community and society in an a-political sphere.
More in the programme document.
